subject: Re: [junit] Completeness testing in JUnit
msgSnippet: ... This is a catch-22.  How can you prove to your project lead that your existing test bed is exhaustive? I, personally, would like this myself, not as a
messageBody:
On Sat, 10 Feb 2001 N.Deering@... wrote:

> My project lead has asked me to provide a way to make ABSOLUTELY SURE that
> every line of code (stated as "every possible code branch") gets tested in
> my JUnit test suites. I prefer to think in terms of the behavior of objects
> and methods, not in terms of (procedural) code branches.
>
> His first suggestion was to embed (in every method!) debug code that writes
> to a log and indicates that the method was executed. I do not want to
> pollute my code with piles of:
>
> if (debug_mode) { SomeGlobalLogFile.write("this method happened") }
>
> Any ideas on how to assure him that exhaustive testing of every outcome of
> every public method will prove the system is working right?

This is a catch-22. How can you prove to your project lead that your
existing test bed is exhaustive?

I, personally, would like this myself, not as a measure of correctness,
but as reassurance that I at least exercized everything at least once.
If I leave something untested, it will stand out in the metric as untested.
It may also point to unused/deprecated code which is a nuke candidate.

I agree with your lead. ;)

I haven't taken the time to glance at this more than briefly, but I
certainly don't consider conditional writes a useful solution. I'd go
the JProbe or profiler route using a JVM which supports it.

Heck, look at Runtime.traceMethodCalls(). Find a JVM which does it,
turn it on inside your test harness, and parse the logs afterwards.
